	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif"; 	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri; 	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin; 	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"; 	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast; 	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri; 	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;} --><!--[if gte mso 10]> <mce:style><!   /* Style Definitions */  table.MsoNormalTable 	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal"; 	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0; 	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0; 	mso-style-noshow:yes; 	mso-style-priority:99; 	mso-style-qformat:yes; 	mso-style-parent:""; 	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt; 	mso-para-margin-top:0in; 	mso-para-margin-right:0in; 	mso-para-margin-bottom:10.0pt; 	mso-para-margin-left:0in; 	line-height:115%; 	mso-pagination:widow-orphan; 	font-size:11.0pt; 	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif"; 	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri; 	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin; 	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"; 	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast; 	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri; 	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;} --><!--[endif] --><!--[endif] --></p>
<p><strong>Elisa Foster&nbsp;</strong><span> "</span>Imaging and Imagining the Black Madonna of Le Puy:<span>&nbsp; </span>Ritual, Sacred Images and Race in Late Medieval and Early Modern France<span>"&nbsp; <br /></span></p>
<p><span><strong>Erin Eckhold Sassin</strong> “Examining the German Ledigenheim:<span>&nbsp; </span>Development of a Housing Type, Position in the Urban Fabric and Impact on Central European Housing Reform” <br /></span></p>
<p><strong>Nathaniel Stein</strong> "Authorities of Presence: Robert Gill, the Photographic Survey of India, and the Colonial Sublime"</p>
<h2>2011</h2>
<p><strong>Amanda Lahikainen</strong>&nbsp;"<span style="color:#222222">Unchecked Ideas: Humor and the French Revolution in British&nbsp;</span><span style="color:#222222"></span><span style="color:#222222">Political Graphic Satire, 1789-1805"</span></p>
<h2>2010</h2>
<p><strong>Caitlin Bass</strong>&nbsp;"Home Behind the Wall: The Living Spaces of Late Medieval German Convents"</p>
<p><strong>Divya Heffley</strong>&nbsp;"Vision in Motion: Architectural Space Time Notation and the Dynamic Perception of Space"</p>
<p><strong>Melissa Katz</strong>&nbsp;“Interior Motives:&nbsp; the Vierge ouvrante/Triptych Virgin in Medieval and Early Modern Iberia”</p>
<p><strong>Anne Mitzen</strong>&nbsp;“Gender, Modernism, and Regional Identity: “ The Promotion and Reception of<em>Künstlerinnen&nbsp;</em>in Düsseldorf &nbsp;and the Rhineland, 1890-1920”&nbsp;</p>
<p><strong>Sarah Joan Moran&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong>&nbsp;“Unconventual Women:&nbsp; Politics, Religion, and Image in the Court Beguinages, c. 1585-c.1713”</p>
<p><strong>Mario Pereira&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong>“African Art at the Portuguese Court, c. 1450-1521”</p>
<p><strong>Kathy Quick</strong>&nbsp;“The Narrative Document:&nbsp; Lewis Hine and ‘Social Photography’”</p>
<p><strong>Suzanne Marie Scanlan&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</strong>&nbsp;&nbsp;“Doorways to the Demonic and Divine:&nbsp; Visions of &nbsp;Santa Francesca Romana and the Frescoes of Tor de’Specchi”</p>
<p><strong>Fan Zhang </strong>"Drama Entertains the Spirit": Art, Ritual, and Theatre in Jin and Yuan Dynasty Pingyang, Shanxi, China"</p>
<h2>2009</h2>
<p><strong>Nancy Austin &nbsp;</strong>&nbsp;“Towards a Genealogy of Visual Culture at The Rhode Island &nbsp;School of Design, 1875-1900”</p>
<p><strong>Anna Rodriquez Farrar &nbsp;</strong>&nbsp;&nbsp;“Images of Charles I of England, 1642-1649”</p>
<p><strong>Yi Gu&nbsp;</strong>&nbsp;“Scientizing Vision in China: Photography, Outdoor Sketching, and &nbsp;the&nbsp;Reinvention of Landscape Perception, 1912-1949”</p>
<p><strong>Hope Saska&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong>&nbsp;&nbsp; “Staging the Page : Graphic Caricature in Eighteenth-Century England”&nbsp;</p>
<h2>2008</h2>
<p><strong>Marianna Aguirre</strong>&nbsp;&nbsp;“Artistic Collaboration in Fascist Italy: Ardengo Soffici and Giorgio Morandi”&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>
<p class="style7"><strong>Catherine Anderson</strong>&nbsp;“Embodiments of Empire: Figuring Race in Late Victorian Painting”</p>
<p><strong>Alexis Goodin</strong>&nbsp;“Egypts” in England: The Representation of Ancient Egypt at the Sydenham Crystal Palace”</p>
<p><strong>Laura Hendrickson</strong>&nbsp;“Against Photography: The Idea of Music in Pre-Raphaelite Visual Reform<strong>”</strong></p>
<p class="style7"><strong>Nancy Kay</strong>&nbsp;“The Sacred Public Sculptures in Antwerp: From Their Medieval Origins to the French Revolution”</p>
<p class="style7"><strong>Andrea Lepage&nbsp;</strong>"Arts of the Franciscan Colegio de San Andre’s in Quito:&nbsp; A Process of Cultural Reformation”</p>
<p><strong>Pascale Rihouet</strong>&nbsp;"The Unifying Power of Moving Pictures in Late Medieval and Renaissance Umbria"</p>
  </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">


	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>

				<h1><a href="/academics/art-history/" title="" accesskey="2"><span class="site-title"></span></a></h1><div id="site-slogan" class="slogan banner-subtext"></div>			</div></section>

                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Resources</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-196" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2><a href="http://gradschool.brown.edu/">The Graduate School</a></h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/gradschool/gateway/for-graduate-students">Policies, dissertation guidelines, and forms (funding requests, student status, etc.)</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/gradschool/academics/training-opportunities-events-tools">Mellon Graduate Workshops</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/gradschool/living-resources">Graduate Student&nbsp;Life Offices and Services</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/gradschool/graduate/graduate-student-council">Graduate School Council</a></li>
</ul>
<h2>Selected Local Research Resources</h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="http://dl.lib.brown.edu/libweb/index.php">Brown University Library</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="http://dl.lib.brown.edu/eresources/subject.php?id=31">specialized resources</a>&nbsp;for the History of Art and Architecture</li>
<li><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/University_Library/libs/hay/">John Hay Library</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/John_Carter_Brown_Library/">John Carter Brown Library</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.providenceathenaeum.org/" rel="nofollow">Providence Athenaeum</a></li>
<li><a href="http://dl.lib.brown.edu/">Brown Center for Digital Initiatives</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.rihs.org/" rel="nofollow">Rhode Island Historical Society</a></li>
</ul>
<h2>Grants and Fellowships</h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/uploads/externalgrantsfellowships.pdf" target="_blank">HIAA Department External Grants and Fellowships List</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.efn.org/%7Eacd/resources.html" rel="nofollow">Resources in Art History for Graduate Students</a>&nbsp;– by Adrienne DeAngelis</li>
<li><a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/gradschool/internal-funding-appointments">Graduate School Internal Funding</a></li>
<li><a href="http://gradschool.brown.edu/go/externalfunding">Graduate School External Funding Search Tools</a>&nbsp;(IRIS, SPIN, Cornell Database, etc.)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.gwu.edu/~fellows/" rel="nofollow">OGSAF Database - George Washington University</a></li>
<li><a href="/academics/art-history/kermit-champa-travel-award" title="The Kermit Champa Travel Award" rel="nofollow">Kermit Champa Memorial Fund Travel Award</a></li>
</ul>
<h2>Professional Development and Employment</h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="http://careerdevelopment.brown.edu/grads/index.php">Career Development Center</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Administration/Sheridan_Center/">Sheridan Center for Teaching and Learning</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.h-net.org/" rel="nofollow">H-Net: Humanities and Social Sciences Online</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.collegeart.org/" rel="nofollow">College Art Association</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.sah.org/index.php" rel="nofollow">Society of Architectural Historians</a></li>
<li><a href="http://chronicle.com/" rel="nofollow">Chronicle of Higher Education</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.brown.edu/gradschool/academics-research/professional-development/brown-wheaton-fac">Brown/Wheaton Faculty Fellows Program</a></li>
</ul>
<h2>Affiliated Programs/Centers</h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Departments/Humanities_Center/">The Cogut Center for the Humanities</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/David_Winton_Bell_Gallery/">The David Winton Bell Gallery</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Research/JNBC/index.html">John Nicholas Brown Center</a>&nbsp;for the Study of American Civilization; Public Humanities Program</li>
<li><a href="http://brown.edu/Departments/Joukowsky_Institute/">Joukowsky Institute for Archaeology and the Ancient World</a></li>
<li><a href="http://blogs.brown.edu/memhs/">MEMHS</a>&nbsp;Medieval and Early Modern History Seminar</li>
<li><a href="http://www.pembrokecenter.org" rel="nofollow">Pembroke Center</a>&nbsp;for Teaching and Research on Women</li>
<li><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Departments/Renaissance_Early_Modern_Studies/graduate/">REMS</a>&nbsp;- Renaissance and Early Modern Studies Graduate Colloquium</li>
</ul>
  </div>

  </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div> </div>
			
				
	</div>

 </div>
              </div>
      <!-- end .columns -->
      
            <div id="sidebar-right" class="sidebar third-column column"> 
	
	<div id="calendar" class="clear-block block block-calwidget ">
	
	<h2>CALENDAR</h2>	
		<div class="content"><section class="events-list">
      <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Oct        </span>
        <span class="day">
          20        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  even">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b2132b0-000007c2events%40brown.edu/">Mid-semester deadline. Last day to change from credit to audit in a course (5:00 p.m. deadline).</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Oct        </span>
        <span class="day">
          23        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  odd">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b2276fb-00000c48events%40brown.edu/">Advising period for spring pre-registration. Students in their first through third semesters will need to procure their advising PIN from their advisor in order to register.</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          02        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  even">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b22d593-00000eabevents%40brown.edu/">Date by which advisors must approve sophomore submitted concentrations in ASK to avoid having a "No Concentration" hold placed against the student's Banner registration (5:00 pm deadline)</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          07        </span></h5>

          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>

        <div class="item-list">		
                             	<h3 class="current-site"><a href="">History of Art and Architecture</a></h3>
            
      
        <div class="list">
        
	
	<div class="site-navigation clear-block block block-menu ">

     	<div class="item-list">	
        <h3><a href="">Brown</a></h3>
        <div class="list">
        <ul>
		<li class="first"><a href="/about" rel="nofollow">About Brown</a></li>

				<section id="banner" class="marginator sub-banner">
<a href="/academics/art-history/"><img src="/academics/art-history/sites/all/themes/pawtucket/img/sample-small-banner.jpg" /></a>
<div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/art-history/" title="" accesskey="2"><span class="site-title"></span></a></h1><div id="site-slogan" class="slogan banner-subtext"></div>			</div></section>
		    
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">GRADUATE STUDENT NEWS: Grad Students Take Home Outside Grants!</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 

<article class="content news_story clear-block main-article">

<div class="p details">
    <span class="date">April 22, 2014</span>
</div>









	<div class="body">
		<p>Part of the graduate student experience is applying for external funding, and our History of Art and Architecture grads were particularly successful this year. We congratulate the following students on their awards:</p>
<div class="content" style="margin-top:0.6em; margin-bottom:0.6em">
<p>Monica Bravo will be a Diane and Trevor Morris Fellow at the Huntington Library and Art Collections in Pasadena in July and August of 2014, and will have a Stipend in American Modernism from the Georgia O'Keeffe Research Center in Santa Fe in January through March of 2015.</p>
<p>Emily Handlin’s dissertation project, “Moving Beyond Vision: Eadweard Muybridge in Philadelphia,” was awarded a one-year Luce Fellowship from the ACLS.</p>
<p>Sarah Rovang and Amy Huang each won a Joukowsky Summer Travel Fellowship.<br />In addition, Sarah Rovang has won a&nbsp;John Coolidge Fellowship from the&nbsp;New England Chapter of the Society of Architectural Historians to fund research at the National Archives in Washington, DC and the National Agricultural Library this summer. She will also be conducting research at the Wolfsonian Library in Miami Beach, Florida with a Wolfsonian-FIU Research Fellowship.</p>
</div>
	</div>

	




</article>
 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->
        
                <div id="sidebar-left" class="sidebar first-column column">

				<section id="banner" class="marginator sub-banner">
<a href="/academics/art-history/"><img src="/academics/art-history/sites/all/themes/pawtucket/img/sample-small-banner.jpg" /></a>
<div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/art-history/" title="" accesskey="2"><span class="site-title"></span></a></h1><div id="site-slogan" class="slogan banner-subtext"></div>			</div></section>
		    
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs"> HIAA Congratulates 2014 MA &amp; PhD Graduates!</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 

<article class="content news_story clear-block main-article">

<div class="p details">
    <span class="date">April 18, 2014</span>
</div>






<div style="width: 353px; " class="inline-right photo-wrapper main-image">
	  <a href="/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/images/news/2014/cheers small.png" class="thickbox"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/imagecache/ursa_feature_image/images/news/2014/cheers%20small.png" alt="" title="" width="353" height="266" class="imagecache imagecache-ursa_feature_image"/></a>
  		  </div>





	<div class="body">
		<p>Caleigh Forbes, MA, History of Architecture <br /> Caleigh has accepted a position at the Skyscraper Museum in NY.</p>
<p>Alba Serino, MA, History of Architecture</p>
<p>Mazie Harris, PhD, History of Photography.&nbsp; Mazie has been appointed Assistant Curator in&nbsp;the Department of Photographs at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles.</p>
<p>Kristen Oehlrich, PhD, History of Photography, will be the&nbsp;Post-Doctoral Research and Teaching Fellow in the&nbsp;Graduate Program in the History of Art at&nbsp;Williams College.&nbsp;</p>
<p>Lisa Tom, PhD, History of Art and Architecture</p>
<p>Nathaniel Walker, PhD, Architectural Studies.&nbsp; Nathan will take up a position as&nbsp;Assistant Professor of Architectural History in the Department of Art History at the College of Charleston in South Carolina.</p>
	</div>

	




</article>
 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->

                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Graduate Students, 2016-17</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-201" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2 style="color:#000000; background-color:#ffffff; padding:0.375em">Graduate Students</h2>
<hr />
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2>Julia Barber</h2>
<p><span style="color:#222222">Julia received her B.A. in Art History and French from Swarthmore College in 2009. During her time at Swarthmore, she completed a French-language thesis on Eugène Atget, inspired in part by her work at the Philadelphia Museum of Art with that institution's magnificent collection of Atget's photographs. After graduation, Julia worked as a curatorial assistant at the Cleveland Museum of Art, where she honed her interest in museum and exhibition theory. At Brown, she studies the Linked Ring and other organizations fighting for the acknowledgement of photography as a fine art at the turn of the twentieth century.</span></p>
<p>Contact:&nbsp;<a href="mailto:julia_barber@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Julia_Barber@brown.edu</a>&nbsp;</p>
<h2>Dominic Bate</h2>
<p><span style="color:#222222"><span style="color:#222222"><span><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:179px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/images/Bate_HAA_Profile.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="171" height="166" /></span>Dominic has BA and MA Degrees in Art History from the Courtauld Institute of Art. His postgraduate studies focused on the history of the printed image in France and Italy before 1700 and culminated in his Master's thesis on the English reception of the French engraver Robert Nanteuil. Before coming to Brown Dominic worked in the British Museum's Department of Prints and Drawings where he catalogued their collection of Italian portrait prints in addition to a large number of German portrait prints and nineteenth-century British book-illustrations. Dominic seeks to understand works of art on their own terms by placing the material object at the heart of his research. He is particularly interested in the different ways in which printed images were used and interpreted both within and outside of the cultural and material environments in which they were produced&nbsp;</span></span></span></p>
<p>Contact:&nbsp;<a href="mailto:dominic_bate@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Dominic_Bate@brown.edu</a>&nbsp;</p>
<h2>Ciprian Buzilă</h2>
<p><span style="color:#222222"><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/images/9_4.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="144" /></span>Ciprian Buzilă completed a Master’s in Sacred Space and Vernacular Architecture (2011, Ion Mincu University of Architecture and Urbanism/UAUIM) after obtaining two Bachelor degrees: one in Art History (2003, National University of Arts in Bucharest) and another one in Furniture and Interior Design (2010, UAUIM). He worked as referent at the National Institute for Historic Monuments and as a scientific researcher at UAUIM in Bucharest. He was awarded a “Vasile Pârvan” scholarship (2012-2014) at the Romanian Academy in Rome and a Fulbright Junior Award (2014-2015) at University of Cincinnati. He is interested in history and theory of Historic Preservation, in general, and in the phenomenon of conversion of old buildings, in particular.</span></p>
<p>Contact:&nbsp;<a href="mailto:ciprian_buzila@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Ciprian_Buzila@brown.edu</a>&nbsp;</p>
<h2>Laura Chilson</h2>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:156px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/images/Correct size Laura Chilson.preview.png" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="148" height="195" /></span></p>
<p><span>Laura received her B.A. with Honors from Wellesley College in 2011, where she studied Anthropology and Archaeology. Before arriving at Brown, she attended the Achill Archaeological Field School in Ireland and worked at Old Sturbridge Village in Sturbridge, Massachusetts. She is particularly interested in medieval monastic architecture and spatial analysis.</span></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><span>Contact: <a href="mailto:laura_chilson@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Laura_Chilson@brown.edu</a></span></p>
<h2></h2>
<h2><span>Alexandra Collins Mathwig</span></h2>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:135px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/images/bio pic 4.preview.png" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="127" height="195" /></span></p>
<p><span style="color:#2f2a20">Alexandra Collins Mathwig studies the history of photography, with a particular focus on contemporary American subjects. She received her BA in Art History and Archaeology from Washington University in St. Louis in 2010. Her undergraduate honors thesis, “Not So Beautiful: A Contextual Analysis of Martha Rosler’s Bringing the War Home: House Beautiful,” examined Rosler’s politically motivated series of photomontages on the Vietnam War. She presented a version of this project focusing on the feminist implications of Rosler’s series at the South Eastern College Art Conference in 2010 entitled “False Dichotomies: Martha Rosler’s Bringing the War Home: House Beautiful.” Her current research focuses on John Szarkowski's tenure as Director of Photography at the Museum of Modern Art in New York from 1962 to 1991.&nbsp;</span></p>
<p>Contact: <a href="mailto:alexandra_collins@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Alexandra_Collins@brown.edu</a></p>
<h2>Suzanne Duff</h2>
<p><span style="color:#2f2a20"><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/images/floris_geometria.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="183" /></span>Suzanne specializes</span><span style="color:#2f2a20">&nbsp;in art of the Lowlands in the Early Modern Era, particularly in 16th-century Antwerp. She received her B.A. in Art History from University of Minnesota, Twin Cities, and her M.A. in Art History from University of Washington.&nbsp;</span><span style="color:#2f2a20">Suzanne’s research interests include history and theory of collections, global exchanges, print culture, and art and science in Early Modern Europe.</span></p>
<p><span>Contact: </span><a href="mailto:suzanne_duff@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Suzanne_Duff@brown.edu</a></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2>Jonathan Duval</h2>
<p><span style="color:#2f2a20"><span style="color:#2f2a20"><span><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/images/unnamed_1.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="195" /></span></span><span>Jon studies the history of architecture. He received his BA in Art History and Architectural Studies from Tufts University. Before coming to Brown, he worked for several years at the MIT Museum, where he assisted with architecture and photography exhibitions. Jon is especially interested in architectural representation and the history of architectural education and practice.</span></span></span></p>
<p><span>Contact: </span><a href="mailto:jonathan_duval@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Jonathan_Duval@brown.edu</a></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2>Lia Dykstra</h2>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:190px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/images/BrownID.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="182" height="195" /></span><span>Lia received her B.A. in Medieval Studies and French from Vassar College (2012), after completing an undergraduate thesis on Viollet-le-Duc’s nineteenth century restoration of Notre-Dame cathedral in Paris. Her current research focuses on Spain and Portugal’s use of medieval and medievalizing architecture in international expositions held in the late nineteenth and twentieth centuries. As an S4 fellow, she is interested in using GIS software to examine questions of architectural space in relation to her topic. </span></p>
<p>Contact: <a href="mailto:Lia_Dykstra@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Lia_Dykstra@brown.edu</a></p>
<h2>Michal Goldschmidt</h2>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:138px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/images/Biov2_0.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="130" height="195" /></span></p>
<div style="color:#222222"><span style="color:#2f2a20">Michal received her BA from Queens' College, Cambridge in History of Art, Theology and Religious Studies. She has a MA degree from the Courtauld Institute of Art, where she studied British Modernism with Lisa Tickner. Before coming to Brown, she worked for Tate's research department. Michal is interested in prewar modern art, particularly that of the British Empire.</span></div>
<div><span style="color:#2f2a20"><br /></span></div>
<p>Contact: <a href="mailto:Michal_Goldschmidt@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Michal_Goldschmidt@brown.edu</a></p>
<h2></h2>
<h2></h2>
<h2></h2>
<h2><span style="color:#2f2a20">Sara Hayat</span></h2>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/images/hayatprofileforwebsite.preview.JPG" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="195" /></span>Sara holds a B.Arch and an M.Arch from the University of Miami’s School of Architecture, where she has also co-taught studio courses on and theater- and film-set design with urban historian Jean-François Lejeune and California based media artist Juan Azulay. Her research interests include phenomenological approaches to architecture, theories of spatiality, and the relationship between moving images and the built environment. In her current work at Brown, Sara observes the various attempts within postwar German architectural circles to come to terms with the memory of the Holocaust and the Second World War. She particularly investigates and challenges the former Bauhaus member Otto Bartning’s postwar theory on “working through” the National Socialist past by revisiting and redefining culturally established notions of space.</p>
<p>Contact:&nbsp;<a href="mailto:Sara_Hayat@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Sara_Hayat@brown.edu</a></p>
<h2>Amy Huang&nbsp;</h2>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:138px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/images/NewImageamyhuang.preview.JPG" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="130" height="195" /></span><span>Amy S. Huang joined Brown University in 2010. She specializes in Chinese art history with a focus on literati painting and collecting practices of the Ming and Qing Dynasties. She is currently working on her dissertation, "Meditating on the Past: reading paintings of seventeenth-century Nanjing through the literary tradition of Jinling huaigu." Before coming to Brown, Amy completed a BA in Management Information Systems in Taiwan (2004). After college, her interest in museums brought her to the UK where she received an MA in Museum Studies from University College London (2005). Coming to the United States in 2008 to pursue graduate studies in the history of art , Amy received an MA in Asian Art History from Boston University (2010) with a thesis on the collecting practice s of the 17th-century Chinese art collector Gao Shiqi. Amy 's research has been supported by the Henry Luce Foundation, and she has worked as a curatorial intern in the Museum of Fine Arts Boston and Peabody Essex Museum.&nbsp;</span></p>
<p><span>&nbsp;</span><span>Contact:&nbsp;</span><a href="mailto:amy_huang@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Amy_Huang@brown.edu</a></p>
<h2>I-Fen Huang</h2>
<p><span style="color:#222222">I-Fen Huang is a Ph.D. candidate of late Chinese art. She received her MA from National Taiwan University, served as curator of the Shih-t'ou Shu-wu Collection and worked as a graduate intern at the International Center of Photography in New York prior to coming to Brown. Focusing on the Gu Family style embroidery made in seventeenth-century Shanghai and other regions in southeast China in the succeeding three centuries, her dissertation explores issues such as the commodification of literati culture, and interrelationship between needlecraft and gender in late imperial and modern China. I-Fen’s research has been supported by the Academia Sinica, the Chiang Ching-kuo Foundation for International Scholarly Exchange and the Smithsonian Institution. Her current research at the Freer and Sackler Galleries explores the technical aspect of textile art production and its cultural meanings.</span></p>
<p>Contact:&nbsp;<a href="mailto:i-fen_huang@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">I-Fen_Huang@Brown.edu</a></p>
<p>&nbsp;<br />
<h2>Josie Johnson&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</h2>
</p><p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:154px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/images/josie.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="146" height="195" /></span><span>Josie studies the history of photography. She received her B.A. from  Stanford University, where she studied Art History and Slavic Language  and Literature. Before entering Brown, Josie worked as a curatorial  assistant at the Cantor Arts Center and a curatorial intern at the Art  Institute of Chicago. Her interests include Russian art and  architecture, museum history, and interwar photography.</span></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Contact:&nbsp; <a href="mailto:josie_johnson@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Josie_Johnson@brown.edu</a></p>
<h2>Erica Kinias</h2>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/images/12003902_10153058059307201_1794232836225761488_n_0.thumbnail.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span><span>Erica received her B.A. from Arizona State University in History and Comparative Religious Studies where she studied early Medieval art and literature. She has a M.A. in Museum Studies from the University College London's Institute of Archaeology, where she studied the English country house in post-World War II Britain. Before coming to Brown, Erica worked as curator for Chiddingstone Castle, UK, and as director of the Telluride Historical Museum in Colorado. Erica is interested in medieval art and architecture, particularly the ways in which gender is reflected in the developments of sacred spaces and ritual.</span></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Contact:&nbsp; <a href="mailto:erica_kinias@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Erica_Kinias@brown.edu</a></p>
<h2>Peter Levins</h2>
<p>Contact: <a href="mailto:Peter_Levins@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Peter_Levins@brown.edu</a></p>
<h2><span style="color:#2f2a20">Ruth W. Lo</span></h2>
<p><span style="color:#1a1a1a">Ruth W. Lo is a Ph.D. candidate studying the history of architecture and urbanism. She holds a B.A. in Architecture and a B.A. in Italian Studies from the University of California, Berkeley, where she spent a year studying at the University of Bologna in Italy. She worked at Steven Holl Architects prior to returning to graduate school at Cornell University, where she received her M.A. in the History of Architecture and Urban Development. Her current research is on food, architecture, and urban planning of Rome during the first half of the twentieth century.&nbsp;Ruth is the Donald and Maria Cox Pre-Doctoral Rome Prize Fellow in Modern Italian Studies at the American Academy in Rome during academic years 2013-2015.</span></p>
<p>Contact: <a href="mailto:Ruth_Lo@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Ruth_Lo@Brown.edu</a></p>
<h2>Eloise Maxwell</h2>
<p><br /><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/images/0_4.thumbnail.jpeg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span><span style="color:#222222"><span>Eloise studies the history of photography. She received her B.A. in Art History from the University of Oxford and her M.A. in Art History from the Institute of Fine Arts, NYU. She wrote her MA thesis on the role of abstraction in the work of contemporary photographer James Welling. &nbsp;Eloise has held positions in the Department of Photography at the Museum of Modern Art, New York, the International Center of Photography, New York, and the Richard Avedon Foundation, New York. Eloise’s interests include Postwar American art, the issue of medium specificity as it relates to photography, and alternative photographic processes.&nbsp;</span></span></p>
<p>Contact: <a href="mailto:Eloise_Maxwell@Brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Eloise_Maxwell@Brown.edu</a></p>
<h2>Emilia Mickevicius</h2>
<p><br /><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/images/Emmy.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="146" /></span><span style="color:#222222">Emilia Mickevicius is studying the history of photography in relation to modern and contemporary art. She received her B.A. with Honors from the University of Chicago in 2011, where she studied art history and visual art. In her undergraduate thesis she examined the modernist photographer Paul Strand’s&nbsp;</span><em style="color:#222222">The Mexican Portfolio</em><span style="color:#222222">&nbsp;and subsequent film projects. She also interned at the Art Institute of Chicago in the departments of Prints &amp; Drawings and Photography. Emmy’s interests include the representation of landscape and environment, the legacy of the 1975 George Eastman House exhibition&nbsp;</span><em style="color:#222222">New Topographics</em><span style="color:#222222">, the rise of color in art photography, directorial and tableau photographs, and art theory and criticism.</span></p>
<p>Contact: <a href="mailto:Emilia_Mickevicius@Brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Emilia_Mickevicius@Brown.edu</a></p>
<h2>Emily Monty</h2>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:162px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/images/Emily Monty.preview.JPG" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="154" height="195" /></span><span><span style="color:#000000; background-color:transparent; vertical-align:baseline">Emily Monty joined the graduate program at Brown in 2013 with a focus in Cinquecento Italy. Her research contributes to an understanding of cultural interchange and mobility in the Renaissance, focusing in particular on paintings, engravings, and treatises as sites of knowledge exchange among Italian and Spanish artists at the end of the sixteenth-century. She completed her Master’s in the History of Art at Tufts University in 2012, where she wrote a thesis entitled “Re-forming Translation: Illustrated Scripture in Post-Tridentine Europe.” Her honors thesis (Bates College, 2010), “Lorenzo Ghiberti, Tradition, and Identity: the use of Byzantine prototypes in the north doors for the Florentine Baptistery,” looked at the survival of medieval iconography and style in the early Renaissance.</span></span><span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p><span>Contact: </span><a href="mailto:Emily_Monty@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Emily_Monty@brown.edu</a></p>
<h2>Emily Chace Morash</h2>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:158px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/images/EmilyMorashSeniorpicture.JPG" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="150" height="156" /></span></p>
<p><span style="color:#2f2a20">Emily received her B.A. from Smith College in Art History and Italian Language and Literature (2004), where she spent a year studying in Florence, Italy. Emily then received her M.A. from the University of Virginia in Architectural History (2006). Her M.A. Thesis is titled, “</span><em style="color:#2f2a20">The Città Universitaria and Cultivating a National Identity: Fascist-sponsored Urban Projects and Architecture in Rome.”&nbsp;</em><span style="color:#2f2a20">Emily has worked at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum and is the former president of the Thomas Jefferson Chapter of the Society of Architectural Historians. She has taught for the Historic Preservation Program for RISD’s Continuing Education Department, and is currently a visiting instructor at Connecticut College. &nbsp;Emily’s dissertation,&nbsp;<em>Rethinking Italian Domestic Architecture: Gio Ponti, Milan, and&nbsp;</em>Lo Stile<em>, 1941-1947,&nbsp;</em></span><span style="color:#2f2a20"><span>&nbsp;examines the development of domestic architecture in the final years of the fascist period and the Second World War and into the immediate postwar period. Her research interests include modern domestic architecture, the role media (film,&nbsp;periodicals, and other publications) plays in the development of modern architecture, and the publicity of modern architecture through exhibitions. Emily has presented her research at the NESAH Student Symposium and at the Annual Meetings of the Society of Architectural Historians.</span></span></p>
<p>Contact:&nbsp;<a href="mailto:emily_morash@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Emily_Morash@Brown.edu</a></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2>Allison Pappas</h2>
<p><span style="color:#222222"><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:164px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/images/APAPPAS.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="156" height="195" /></span>Allison studies the history of photography. She comes to Brown from the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, where she was assistant curator of photography. She has also held positions in the Department of Photographs at the J. Paul Getty Museum, the Department of Photography at the Museum of Modern Art, New York, the Williams College Museum of Art, and the Williamstown Art Conservation Center. Allison is delighted to be back at Brown, where she received a B.A. in History of Art and Architecture and a B.A. in Anthropology, with honors. She holds an M.A. from Williams College in History of Art.  Photo courtesy of Keliy Anderson-Staley</span></p>
<p>Contact:&nbsp;<a href="mailto:Allison_Pappas@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Allison_Pappas@brown.edu</a>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2>Bill Skinner</h2>
<p><span><br /><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/images/unnamed_0.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="130" /></span>Bill studies architectural history. His interests include the history of technology, colonialism and the relationship between the built and natural environments in the British West Indies. &nbsp;Bill’s current research looks at the development of experimental architecture through the design, manufacture, transport and assembly of military structures in Barbados and elsewhere during the 19th century. He holds a B.S. in Industrial Design from the University of the Arts and an M.A. in the History of Architecture and Urban Development from Cornell University.&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="p1">Contact: <a href="mailto:William_Skinner@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">William_Skinner@brown.edu</a></p>
<h2>Rebecca Szantyr</h2>
<p style="color:#222222"><span><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/images/Szantyr-head shot.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="168" /></span>Rebecca Szantyr researches the visual and material culture of the global 18<sup>th</sup>&nbsp;century. After receiving her B.A. in art history from Vassar College in 2003, she worked for a prominent dealer of 19<sup>th</sup>&nbsp;century European and American painting before commencing her graduate studies.&nbsp; As a recipient of the Cleveland Museum of Art Fellowship, she completed her M.A. in Art History at Case Western Reserve University in 2010, writing a master’s thesis that examined Johan Zoffany’s conversation pieces in India before and after the 1785 departure of Governor-General Warren Hastings.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></p>
<p style="color:#222222"><span>At Brown, Rebecca’s work concentrates on the Atlantic World during the long 18</span><sup>th</sup><span>&nbsp;century.</span><span>&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span>Her qualifying paper, “White-Washing the Docklands: Visualizing London’s Maritime East End” investigates representations of black mariners in print and the cityscape in the decades following the American Revolutionary War. Her dissertation reappraises the artistic category of “colonial American,” through the case of John Greenwood, an artist whose life and career crossed the Anglo-Dutch Atlantic.</span></p>
<p style="color:#222222"><span>Rebecca has held positions in the curatorial departments of the Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center, Cleveland Museum of Art, Yale Center for British Art, and the Rhode Island School of Design Museum.</span></p>
<p>Contact:&nbsp;<a href="mailto:rebecca_szantyr@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Rebecca_Szantyr@brown.edu</a></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2><span style="color:#2f2a20">Kelly Whitford</span></h2>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/images/Maderno, S. Cecilia, Chirch of S. Cecilia, Rome (photo by author)_1.preview.JPG" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="146" /></span>Kelly received her B.A in Art History from Carleton College (2006) and her M.A. in Art History from the University of Oregon (2011).&nbsp; Her work focuses on Rome during the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.&nbsp; Specifically, Kelly’s research examines Church rituals and ceremonies (especially pilgrimage), and the ways in which these performances incorporated statues, architecture, and public space.</p>
<p>Contact: <a href="mailto:kelly_whitford@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Kelly_Whitford@brown.edu</a></p>

        <div class="marginator">
          <h1><a href="http://www.brown.edu" accesskey="1" title="Brown University Homepage"><img src="/academics/art-history/sites/all/themes/pawtucket/img/brown-logo.png" alt="Brown University Seal" /><span>Brown University</span></a></h1>
            <section id="mobile-navigation">
  <div class="marginator">

                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-12" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p>The Department of the History of Art offers students two separate concentrations. Students can choose to concentrate in the History of Art and Architecture or in Architectural Studies. The two concentrations are allied, but they also have different goals and requirements. What they share is stated here. You can find the different requirements and goals for each by clicking on the links for the two concentrations.</p>
<p>Whether you choose to concentrate in the History of Art and Architecture or in Architectural Studies, the Department's goal is to provide you with a strong theoretical and historical understanding of the visual and material environment created by humankind. You will encounter a vast range of works, from the most recognized buildings, paintings, and sculptures to deeper layers of material culture. In courses that span history you will explore the past as a foreign country with all its surprises and different from what you might expect. And you will range across the globe in courses that embrace human creation throughout the world.</p>
<p>Both concentrations aim to engage you with the history of art and architecture as a humanistic discipline. You will master the different analytical tools that have been developed and are currently used in practice to expand our knowledge of art and material culture in history. These include a wide spectrum of approaches, from gender theory and the structural analysis of buildings to direct familiarity with the classification by date and style of artworks and material culture or the relationship between production of paintings and the history of economics. &nbsp;In your courses, you will discover the history of art and architecture as a lively field of inquiry, embracing theoretical questions that open up new areas and issues. Your path into understanding new cultures and historical periods also will be opened by learning to read at least one foreign language as part of what both concentrations require.</p>
<p>Both concentrations will prepare you to choose from a variety of professional goals. Our graduates have built careers in higher education, museum work, the art market, architectural history and practice, historic preservation, publishing, cultural property law, and other fields.</p>
<h2>Concentration Advising</h2>
<p>Students who wish to concentrate in the History of Art and Architecture or Architectural Studies are welcome to do so after consultation with the Departmental Undergraduate Supervisor, Professor Jeffrey Muller (<a href="mailto:jeffrey_muller@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">jeffrey_muller@brown.edu</a>, office hours: &nbsp; &nbsp; Fall 2017 semester Tue 2:30-4:30p . Thur 11:00a-12:00p<br />&nbsp;List Art Building 411)</p>
<p>Students who wish to concentrate in the Brown/RISD Architecture concentration are welcome to do so after consultation with one of the Architecture Undergraduate Supervisors, Professor Dietrich Neumann(<a href="mailto:Dietrich_Neumann@brown.edu">Dietrich_Neumann@brown.edu</a>, office hours: Wed 2:30-3:30 List ARt Building 412), Professor Itohan Osayimwese (<a href="mailto:Itohan_Osayimwese@brown.edu">Itohan_Osayimwese@brown.edu</a>, office hours: &nbsp;Tue 1:00-2:20p List Art Building 414), or Professor Sheila Bonde, (<a href="mailto:Sheila_Bonde@Brown.edu">Sheila_Bonde@Brown.edu</a>, office hours: Tue 1:30-3:00p List Art Building 413).</p>
<p>The Concentration Supervisor should be consulted for matters concerning course selection, approval to take RISD courses, approval to study abroad, and the final approval of transfer credits for courses taken outside of Brown.</p>
<h2>Taking RISD Courses</h2>
<p>Brown students may take as many as 4 courses at the Rhode Island School of Design (History of Art and Architecture concentrators can count only 2 of these for concentration credit). Only two circumstances will require a student to petition in advance of registration: when students wish to study at RISD for 5 or more courses and when students intend to enroll in a RISD course that satisfies RISD's Liberal Arts degree requirements. The Committee on Academic Standing (CAS) demands that students who desire to have more than 4 RISD courses counted toward their Brown degree present an academic rationale in each instance. In the event of Brown/RISD curricular overlap, students are asked to enroll in the Brown course.&nbsp; Please see link to Brown registrar guidelines:<br /><a href="https://www.brown.edu/about/administration/registrar/couse-enrollment/registraton#risd">https://www.brown.edu/about/administration/registrar/course-enrollment/registration#risd</a></p>
<h2>Study Abroad Programs/Summer School</h2>
<p>Information on approved programs for study abroad may be obtained at the Office of International Programs in J. Walter Wilson Buidling,&nbsp; Suite 510.&nbsp; Forms necessary for preliminary and final approval are also available there for the concentration advisor's signature. Transfer credits will be counted as lecture courses rather than seminars. Concentrators may receive concentration credit for two courses taken abroad. Summer courses require advance approval from the concentration advisor, and should be at least five weeks long, excluding the final examination, in order to count for Brown credit.</p>
  </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">


	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>
 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->

        <div>
        <h5>Information For:</h5>
        <ul>
          <li class="first"><a href="/gateway/current-students" rel="nofollow">Current Students</a></li>
          <li><a href="/gateway/faculty" rel="nofollow">Faculty</a></li>

          <li><a href="/gateway/families" rel="nofollow">Families</a></li>

				<section id="banner" class="marginator sub-banner">
<a href="/academics/art-history/"><img src="/academics/art-history/sites/all/themes/pawtucket/img/sample-small-banner.jpg" /></a>
<div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/art-history/" title="" accesskey="2"><span class="site-title"></span></a></h1><div id="site-slogan" class="slogan banner-subtext"></div>			</div></section>
		    
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Architecture</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-810" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2><span>Architecture at Brown and RISD</span></h2>
<h2></h2>
<h3>Bachelor of Arts in Architecture + Masters of Architecture</h3>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:518px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/art-history/sites/brown.edu.academics.art-history/files/images/iStock_24863931_XXLARGE.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-_original " width="510" height="193" /></span></p>
<p>The concept for this new concentration has evolved in response to continuous interest among our students, and in discussions with the architecture department at the Rhode Island School of Design.</p>
<p>The concentration has been designed in order for students to develop a broad understanding of the concepts and methods for the planning and design of buildings, landscapes, and cities. In significant contrasts with other architecture undergraduate majors, it has also been planned with the explicit goal of connecting architectural training firmly with the humanities and providing a greater awareness of global, environmental, social and economic issues in the built environment. &nbsp;This approach to the education of architects and urban planners is meant to provide them with the tools needed in today’s urban global society. It will also bring together two strengths of Brown and RISD.</p>
<h4>Curriculum</h4>
<p>By combining a carefully selected range of classes in the fields of the architectural design, the humanities, technology, urban life and theory, Brown students will acquire an increased proficiency for pursuing a graduate degree in architecture. The new concentration at Brown will require a sequence of at least 14 classes (or 42 credits - the time intensive studio classes will be double credit). The students will take at least two double credit studio design classes (offered either at Brown or at RISD), and at least 18 credits of architectural technology, architectural history, construction or architectural drawing, plus at least 6 credits of liberal arts classes on subjects such as urban literature, theatre set design, social sciences, modern culture and media etc. (see sample classes below)</p>
<p>Students in this concentration will probably find the design studios the most unusual part of their experience at Brown. They require (much) more time than seminars or lecture courses and they take place in a workshop atmosphere, in which independent motivation and focus are as crucial as the willingness to collaborate and learn from each other. In these studios individual designs of buildings and urban areas are prepared by students and then analyzed and critiqued by the faculty and, usually twice a semester, by invited guests.</p>
<h4>Inspiration and Philosophy</h4>
<h4></h4>
<p>The planning of the concentration has profited greatly from closely examining similar courses of study at peer institutions, such as Princeton, Harvard and Yale, and from the advice of deans at additional institutions, before, during and after a major symposium jointly organized by Brown and RISD on April 24/25 2015, called “Architecture, Urbanism and the Humanities.” Among the speakers were Amale Andros (Columbia), Nader Tehrani (MIT), Stan Allan (Princeton), Kent Kleinman (Cornell), Nicholas Boyarski (AA London), Matthias Sauerbruch (Akademie der Künste, Berlin), Martha Thorne (IE Madrid), Bernard Tschumi (Columbia). It became clear that the concept of this new concentration at Brown has the chance of playing a unique role among comparable programs, due to the collaboration of two distinct institutions with their own cultures, and a stronger than usual emphasis on a broad interdisciplinary &nbsp;integration of design with the humanities, engineering and the social sciences. Our program will grow in close collaborations and exchange with above listed colleagues, who promised to remain engaged in its evolution.</p>
<p>The selection of courses and style of the studios will emphasize as much as possible a ‘learning from precedent’ and a stronger focus on solutions for real world problems, rather than on abstract formal exercises. While abstraction always forms an important element in any architectural training, we hope students will also learn to see and observe in a profound way, read, measure, analyze their environment, develop opinions about what works and what doesn't, find out how light flows and changes, how it can be manipulated, how spatial sequences function, etc. While training in digital representation has to be part of any architectural education today, we also want to emphasize the value of learning to sketch and draw, the craft of making models by hand rather than ‘3D-print’ them. We hope to strengthen ties with the Department of Theatre Arts and Performance Studies in order to give room to the notion of narrative in architecture, a notoriously underdeveloped subject in architectural education. How do spaces generate action, facilitate or prevent certain functions?</p>
<h4>“Advanced Standing” and “4+2”</h4>
<p>Students in the concentration have the option to qualify for ‘advanced standing.’ They will be able to transition into a 2 year program at RISD or several other architecture schools, concluded by an MArch degree from that institution. The above described course selection follows the suggestions of the National Colleges of Architecture Accreditation Board (NAAB), but, of course, each case will have to be approved by RISD or any other institution that accepts students with a certificate of ‘advanced standing.’</p>
<p>The scope of courses for advanced standing is as follows (according to RISD’s requirement for the acceptance to the Advanced Standing track): “Applicants must have completed a four-year undergraduate degree with a major in architecture, at an accredited College or University. These applicants should have completed at least 2 semesters of 6 credit studios in Architecture and, in the view of the admission committee, demonstrate a high degree of design proficiency, the equivalent to two semesters of graduate level studio work. In addition applicants must have completed 24 credits (or equivalent) of architecture courses including 18 credits of architectural technology, architectural history, construction or architectural drawing. Another 6 credits of undergraduate coursework would be credited for a total of 42 credits. A minimum grade of B is required for any course to count towards advanced standing. The acceptance to the&nbsp;advanced standing track is at the sole discretion of the admission committee. Successful advanced standing track applicants typically complete their degree requirements in 2 years.” All students, however, will end up with much more and better material for their portfolios (a collection of work samples) which they submit when applying to architecture schools.</p>
<h4>Study abroad</h4>
<p>We hope that many students will make use of study abroad options, although the option is not required. &nbsp;&nbsp;Students who elect to pursue the study abroad option will most likely do so in the second semester of their junior year. We have already discussed arrangements specific to the new concentration with the AEDES campus in Berlin in collaboration with Bard College, with our partner university in Madrid, “IE” and the architecture school at their Segovia campus, which is particularly well suited for this particular purpose, and RISD’s Rome program. These programs would offer one studio and one architectural history course, as well as language instructions.</p>
<p>From the 2016/17 AY onwards Brown will – in all likelihood - offer 5 week condensed winter sessions from late December through January. These new course times and formats will be advantageous for our collaboration. Studio courses could be taken during winter session in Berlin at AEDES for example. Discussions are also under way with a non-profit organization in Guatemala in order to provide a sustainable design/build workshop in San Antonio/Panajachel during winter session.</p>
<h4>Declaring the Concentration</h4>
<p>This new concentration would be declared at the end of the Sophomore year, but courses counting towards it could already taken earlier. In particular, the Introduction to Architectural Design that is offered every spring is considered a prerequisite and a ‘testing ground’ for interested students and should ideally be taken before declaring the concentration.</p>
<h4>Changing the Concentration</h4>
<p>As there is a certain amount of overlap between the new ‘architecture’ concentration (14 courses) and the existing ‘architectural studies’ concentration (10 courses), students will be able to switch to ‘architectural studies’ during either junior or senior year if they realize that the 14 required classes are not feasible for them.</p>
<h4>Numbers of students expected</h4>
<p>We currently have 25 students on a waitlist for “Introduction to Architectural Design” in the spring. From these, we expect ca. 5 students to apply for the new concentration. This number could grow to 12 in the coming years, which is a good studio size, given the amount of time spent on individual and group critiques. Our colleagues at RISD have agreed to accommodate our students in their current design courses.</p>
<h4></h4>
<h4>Capstone / Honors projects</h4>
<p>For students in the concentration who intend to go to architecture school afterwards, typically their design project in their double credit second studio will be ideal for a capstone or honors project. For others, who might tend towards theory or history of architecture, an honors thesis is still a valid option.</p>
<h4>Internships</h4>
<p>No experience is as useful for a potential future architect than the exposure to the realities of work in an architectural office. Our department has a long history of placing our students in local, and East Coast design firms as interns (LLB Architects, Friedrich St. Florian, Bjarke Ingels, Richter Tightman, Robert Venturi etc.) We continue to expand our list of contacts and urge students to take on internships while enrolled in our program. An independent study in conjunction with an internship is a good possibility.</p>
<h4>WRIT requirement</h4>
<p>In order to ensure that students in this program acquire good writing skills, we have designated several of the courses in the history of architecture (which already have a substantial writing requirement) as WRIT courses. There are a number of electives (Urban literature, for example) that also have a WRIT designation.</p>
<h4>Collaborations</h4>
<p>As a very interdisciplinary concentration the new architecture major will require new models of collaboration both within Brown (History of Art and Architecture, Urban Studies, Theatre and Performing Arts, Engineering etc.) and with the Rhode Island School of Design (Architecture, Interior Architecture). It will also seek collaboration with other recent initiatives at Brown in the area of art, design and urban improvements, such as the Creative Arts Council, the Brown Design Workshop (BDW) at the School of Engineering, Brown TRI-LAB, which brings together “students, faculty and community practitioners to engage with a complex social issue and collaboratively develop, refine and test solutions to the issue,” and Brown Design for America at the John Street Studio, operated through the Theatre Arts and Performance Studies Department.</p>
<p>At RISD we have worked very closely with the department of architecture (Laura Briggs and Hansy Better) and we hope to include classes at RISD’s IntAR department as well. While Brown is planning to include winter sessions in its curriculum, the calendar of both schools will still not be entirely aligned in the foreseeable future. This will mean that students in our program taking classes at RISD might meet with their instructors once or twice before the RISD semester begins and continue to take classes for another week or two after Brown’s semester ends.</p>
<h4>Space</h4>
<p>We hope to continue our longstanding collaboration with the Department of Theatre Arts and Performance Studies and use 50 John Street as a studio space for the introductory classes. Classes at RISD will accommodate students at the BEB and IntAR studio spaces. Over the past year, a number of new ‘maker spaces’ have evolved at Brown, and we hope to become one of the foci of this network, as our students will create models (both analytical models of historical or contemporary architecture and their own designs), pieces of furniture, furnishings, objects at studios all over campus, such as in Prince Lab, Tockwotton, 50 John Street, the future lab at the Rockefeller Library etc.</p>
<h4>Faculty</h4>
<p>The new concentration relies upon existing faculty and resources at both institutions. The single exception is the Introductory design studio course at Brown, taught for many years by Prof. Neumann.</p>
<p>For the past several years, we have hired adjunct faculty with expertise in architecture and design to teach the course and will continue to do so, depending upon availability of funding.</p>
<h4>Advising</h4>
<p>We will always have a team of dedicated advisors for this program at both schools. At RISD it will be Profs Laura Briggs, Hansy Better and Jonathan Knowles (or the current chair of the architecture school and director of graduate studies, plus one studio teacher). At Brown, we will share the advising among the three professors predominantly involved with architecture: Sheila Bonde, Itohan Osayimwese, Dietrich Neumann. We will provide regularly updated information about the advising structure on a dedicated website for the concentration and on Focal Point. Our current ‘standing committee’ of two Brown and two RISD faculty will continue to discuss and resolve any issues that arise as the program evolves.</p>
<h4>Prerequisites and sample program</h4>
<p>We highly recommend that students first take the “Introduction to Architectural Design Studio” during spring of their sophomore year, in order to try their inclination towards and talent for architectural design. Depending on enrollment figures we might introduce a selection process for the concentration based on a portfolio of previous work. Below is a list with sample courses for the Brown undergraduate architecture major, to be taken during a student’s four years at Brown, most of them after declaring the concentration at the end of their Sophomore year. These requirements are meant to fulfill entrance requirements for “advanced standing” in several architecture schools such as RISD’s. At Brown the program will bring together the Engineering School, Urban Studies, History of Art and Architecture and other social sciences and humanities departments. In case a student is given the certificate of “advanced standing,” design studios and other classes follow at RISD in year 5 &nbsp;and 6, if not, in year 5, 6 and 7.</p>
<h4>Prerequisites:</h4>
<p>BROWN HIAA 0100 Intro Design Studio (Carpenter) (3 credits)</p>
<p>Many architecture schools require one each of introductory level math and physics classes. &nbsp;For example:</p>
<p>MATH 0090, 0100 or 0170 or 0190<br />PHYS 0030<br /><strong>Two double credit Design Studios</strong><br />- RISD/BROWN ARCH 2102 Architectural Design Studio (6 credits)<br />- RISD/BROWN ARCH 2103 Advanced Design Studio (6 credits)<br />Six Core requirements (“at least 18 credits of architectural technology, architectural history, construction or architectural drawing”). (Select four classes from RISD, two from Brown.)<br />RISD ARCH 2141 (Fall) Architectural Projection (Lostritto)<br />RISD ARCH 2142 (Spring) Architectural Analysis (Bardt)<br />RISD ARCH 2152 Structural Analysis (Schneider)<br />RISD ARCH 2153 Wood Structures (Nelson)<br />RISD ARCH 2158 Environmental Design (tba)</p>
<p>HIAA 0010 A Global History of Art and Architecture (Bonde/Martin)<br />HIAA 0046 Islamic Architecture (Bonde)<br />HIAA 0081 Architecture of the House (Osayimwese)<br />HIAA 0090 The other history of Modern Architecture (Osayimwese)<br />HIAA 1190 Spaces and Institutions of Modernity (Osayimwese)<br />HIAA 0770 Architecture and Urbanism of the African Diaspora (Osayimwese)<br />HIAA 1181 Prefabrication and Architecture (Osayimwese)<br />HIAA 0850 Modern Architecture (Neumann) or<br />HIAA 0860 Contemporary Architecture (Neumann) or<br />HIAA 0700 19th Century Architecture (Neumann)</p>
<p><strong>The remaining 6 electives should contain two classes in Engineering, two in the Humanities and two in another field.</strong></p>
<h4>Electives</h4>
<p><strong>History and Theory</strong><br />HIAA 0420 Cathedrals and Castles (Bonde)<br />HIAA 0070 19th Century Architecture (Dietrich Neumann)<br />HIAA 0086 Contemporary Architecture (Dietrich Neumann)<br />HIAA 0090 Film Architecture (Dietrich Neumann)<br />HIAA 0081 Architecture of the House (Osayimwese)<br />HIAA 0090 The other history of Modern Architecture (Osayimwese)<br />HIAA 1190 Spaces and Institutions of Modernity (Osayimwese)<br />HIAA 0770 Architecture and Urbanism of the African Diaspora (Osayimwese)<br />HIAA 1181 Prefabrication and Architecture (Osayimwese)<br />HIAA 1440 The Medieval Monastery (Bonde)<br />HIAA 1910 Water and Architecture (Bonde)<br />HIAA 0560 Constructing the Eternal City: Popes and Pilgrims in Renaissance Rome (Lincoln)<br />HIAA 0191 The Architecture of downtown Providence (Dietrich Neumann)<br />HIST1976Y Energy and Environment in American (Lucier)</p>
<p><strong>Engineering and Design<br /></strong>ENGN0030 Intro to Engineering&nbsp;<br />ENGN0040 Dynamics and Vibrations (Bower/Franck)<br />ENGN0930A Appropriate Technologies (Barrett Hazeltine)<br />ENGN0903 DesignStudio (Ian Gonsher)<br />ENGN1000 &nbsp;Projects in Engineering Design (Ian Gonsher)<br />ENGN1930 Renewable Energy Technologies (Chris Bull)<br />ENGN0310 Mechanics of Solids and Structures<br />ENGN1300 Structural Analysis<br />ENGN1380 Structural Design</p>
<p><strong>Additional electives (at least four more classes from the list below)<br /></strong>Art<br />VISA 0100 Studio Foundations (Bostrom a. o.)<br />VISA1420 Sculpture II - Conceptual Propositions (Myoda)<br />VISA1800V Creative Mind Studio (Fishman/ Gonsher)<br />VISA1210K Pixel/Paint/Print (Tarentino)</p>
<p><strong>Theatre and Performance Arts</strong><br />TAPS 0260 Stage Lighting<br />TAPS 1240 Performance Historiography and Theatre History (Ybarra)<br />TAPS 1280F Introduction to Set Design<br />TAPS 1300 Advanced Set Design<br />&nbsp;<br /><strong>Environmental Studies</strong><br />RISD INTAR 2318-01: Building Structures, Systems, Reuse (Rudorf)<br />RISD ARCH 2156 Environmental Design (tba)<br />ENVS 0410 Environmental Stewardship (Kurt Teichert)<br />ENVS 1400 Sustainable Design in the Built Environment (Kurt Teichert)<br />ENVS 0110 Humans, Nature, and the Environment: Addressing Environmental Change in the 21st Century</p>
<p><strong>Urban Politics and Social Sciences</strong><br />URBN 0210 The&nbsp;City: An Intro to &nbsp;Urban America (Neumann)<br />URBN1570 Guts of the City: Interdisciplinary Perspectives on Urban Infrastructure and Environmental&nbsp;Planning (Teichert)<br />URBN 1000 Fieldwork in the Urban Community<br />URBN 1870C The Environment Built: Urban Environmental History and Urban Environmentalism for the&nbsp;21st Century (Haffner)<br />POLS 1730 Environmental Politics in the United States (Affigne)<br />POLS 0220 City&nbsp;Politics&nbsp; (James Morone)<br />SOC1871 Principles and Methods of GIS<br />PPAI1701Q Leading Social Ventures: Social Entrepreneurship in Action (Alan Harlam)<br />PPAI1910 Social Entrepreneurship (Harlam)</p>
<p><strong>History and Archaeology</strong><br />LAST1510 Urban Latin America&nbsp;<br />JAPN0910 Japanese&nbsp;Cities: Tokyo &amp; Kyoto<br />ARCH 1900 The Archaeology of College Hill<br />COLT1810 Tales of Two&nbsp;Cities&nbsp;Havana - Miami<br />1420 Urbanization in China</p>
<p><strong>Literature</strong><br />ENGL 1760 Reading New York<br />HISP1500 Representations of Barcelona</p>
<h4>SAMPLE PROGRAM:</h4>
<p><br /><strong>Highly recommended:</strong><br />MATH 0090<br />PHYS 0030</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:</strong><br />BROWN HIAA 0100 Intro Design Studio (Carpenter) (3 credits)</p>
<p><strong>Six Core requirements:</strong><br />RISD ARCH 2141 (Fall) Architectural Projection (Lostritto)<br />RISD ARCH 2142 (Spring) Architectural Analysis (Bardt)<br />RISD ARCH 2152 Structural Analysis (Schneider)<br />RISD ARCH 2153 Wood Structures (Nelson) or RISD ARCH 2158 Environmental Design (tba)<br />HIAA A Global history of Art and Architecture (Bonde/Martin)<br />HIAA 0850 Modern Architecture (Dietrich Neumann)</p>
<p><strong>Two electives in the Humanities/Liberal Arts:</strong><br />JAPN0910 Japanese&nbsp;Cities: Tokyo &amp; Kyoto<br />TAPS 1280F Introduction to Set Design</p>
<p><strong>Two electives in Engineering:</strong><br />ENGN0930A Appropriate Technologies (Barrett Hazeltine)<br />ENGN0903 DesignStudio (Ian Gonsher)</p>
<p><strong>Two additional electives:</strong><br />URBN 1870C The Environment Built: Urban Environmental History and Urban Environmentalism for the 21st Century (Haffner)<br />POLS 0220 City&nbsp;Politics&nbsp; (James Morone)</p>
<p><br /><br /><br /><br /></p>
<div class="image-clear"></div>  </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
